I am in agreement with Airly. I could see the ground thing in that
much like a loud sound could rattle your chest, like at a conscert and
you can feel the beat in your chest. But what do you mean by flashes
of lightning?

Just making sure I have a clear understanding before I have a clear
understanding. Tuscon's sonic roar could be as loud as thunder and
even perhaps sound like it, but would not be thunder in the sense of
being part of the weather patterns.

For instance nearby thunder can range as loud as 120 Db. For
references: This is roughly the equivalent to being within 200 feet of
a jet aircraft during take-off or about 3 feet from an auto horn. A
chain saw is rated around 100 decibels. A sound of 140 decibels is
painfully loud. [Note each 10 decibel increase in noise level seems
twice as loud.]

I would imagine that Tuscon is probrably like Brawl in this matter,
but more effective in its use, meaning he can hit at almost 300 Db if
conscentrated into a blast, probrably 200 in a cone and 150 in a wave.

300 (BEAM) can blow out metal and concrete and such like. Basically as
powerful as any blast Megatron, Gavatron, Optimus Prime, Rodimus or
any other leader type can deliver. It is just created from Sonic
energies rather than more conventional energies.

200 (CONE) Could concievably kill a human and probrably cause serious
damage on some of the sensative inner workings of a transformer. Could
do things like blow out glass and other unprotected crystalized
materials.

150 (CIRCLE) Painfully loud and POSSIBLY stunning affects.

Here is a list of Db counts. I cannot say I would follow it
religiously, since this is a Scifi settings and the transformers are
not human, but it would give you an idea and could spark creativity.
However some things may not work exactly as planned. So if you are
going to try something special, PLEASE talk it over with me first.

http://www.makeitlouder.com/Decibel%20Level%20Chart.txt

I hope all this gives food for thought.

- Preston

> Perhaps just the lightning flashes would suffice.  Sort of showing that in
> darkness there is a light of hope.
